title: Wife's 911 call after her Australian husband Brenton Estorffe was shot dead in their Texas home
text:
The harrowing 911 call made by a young mother whose Australian husband had just been shot by home intruders in the US has been revealed.

Brenton Estorffe, 29, was gunned down in the lounge room of his home in Fort Bend County, Texas, just after midnight local time on Wednesday.

His wife Angelenna Estorffe trembled during her emergency call to police, as she told the operator she was too scared to leave her room with her two children, aged one and three.

'I don't know. I'm so scared to walk over there. They shot him. Oh my God, I think he's really hurt,' Ms Estorffe said in the audio of the call, released by 7News.

'Baby are you okay... babe are you okay?'

Angelenna Estorffe was unable to leave her bedroom after hearing her husband Brenton Estorffe (right) get shot by two intruders

Mr Estorffe - an aspiring NFL player - desperately fought to stop his attackers from getting to his wife and children.

He died just three minutes after turning 29.

The father, from Queensland's Sunshine Coast, was killed after getting up to investigate the sound of a glass door smash in the middle of the night.

Two intruders smashed the window of the Estorffe family home on Wednesday night

Mr Estorffe desperately tried to fight the attackers to stop them from getting to his wife and two children

Ms Estorffee told police she had heard glass shattering before her husband jumped up to check what was happening.

She was unable to tell police if the intruders were still inside her home during the call.

'No I don't think so but I'm so scared I can't walk over to my husband,' she said.

'I'm so sorry I have two kids in the house. I don't know what to do.

'I'm just, I'm freaking out really bad right now ... and I'm trying to get the number of my neighbour.'

'No I don't think so but I'm so scared I can't walk over to my husband,' Ms Estorffe told police during a 911 phone call

Police have released a 'vehicle of interest' (pictured) that the intruders are believed to have fled the scene in

Surveillance footage of a 'vehicle of interest' was released on Saturday by police in a bid to track down the intruders.

A $25,000 reward is on offer for the person who can assist in finding the offenders.

The devastated parents of Mr Estorffe received a series of frantic phone calls confirming their son had died.

'He wrestled those two blokes away from his wife and kids. That's when they shot him. Unfortunately he paid the highest price,' father Michael Estorffe said.

He had initially been struggling to secure a visa to attend his son's funeral to be held on Tuesday.

Mr Estorffe's visa was granted and he was able to fly into Texas on Sunday, telling reporters his priority was just to spend time with the family.

'It still really hasn't sunk in that it's real,' he said as he tried to choke back the tears at the airport.

Michael Estorffe (pictured right) said he hasn't been able to sleep since learning his son had been killed in home invasion
description: Brenton Estorffe, 29, was shot dead in the lounge room of his home in Fort Bend County, Texas, just after midnight on Wednesday.
authors: Paula Ahillon For Daily Mail Australia
